Title: An animal without aerobic cellular respiration
Abstract:
Aerobic respiration is the hallmark of almost all cellular
life, with only a few protists having lost this ability, and
mitochondria within eukaryotes. Proteins involved in cellular
respiration are encoded either in the nuclear or mitochondrial (mt)
genomes. Heretofore, all animal mitochondria were thought to possess
their own genomes. The Myxozoa are a large group of parasitic Cnidaria
(corals, jellyfish) with a very simple body organization. We have
discovered using microscopic and genomic approaches that the myxozoan
Henneguya salminicola, has lost its mt genome, and thus the ability to
perform aerobic cellular respiration. We could not identify any
mitochondria-encoded genes in the genome and transcriptome of this
species. In parallel with the apparent loss of the mt genome, this
myxozoan has lost almost all nuclear genes involved in transcription and
replication of the mt genome. Similarly, key mt metabolic enzymes
encoded in the nucleus such as the pyruvate dehydrogenase are detectable
only as pseudogenes. The identification of these pseudogenes supports
the view that the absence of a mt genome is not an artifact. By
contrast, using the same sequencing methods, we also report the presence
of mt genome in the Myxozoa Myxobolus squamalis showing that our
approaches successfully identify mt genome when present. The molecular
results are supported by fluorescence micrographs that show the presence
mt DNA in M. squamalis but not in H. salminicola. The discovery of an
animal without mt genome provides a new model species for the
understanding of the evolutionary transition from an aerobic to an
exclusive anaerobic metabolism. Evolutionary drivers for the loss of the
mt genomes in H. salminicola might include redundancy, as metabolites
are available from the host, and low oxygen availability in the host
tissues where the parasite replicates.
